newsitem.title: USA: Meeting touted as effort to rescue pulp mill.
newsitem.headline: Meeting touted as effort to rescue pulp mill.

text.p: Top government and corporate officials will seek to negotiate a reprieve for the troubled Ketchikan Pulp Co. mill at a meeting Wednesday in Washington.

The meeting, between Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman, Alaska Gov. Tony Knowles, Alaska's Congressional delegation and Louisiana-Pacific Corp. Chairman Mark Suwyn, has been touted as a last-ditch effort to avert a shutdown of the pulp mill owned by the company's Ketchikan subsidiary.
Knowles said he is hopeful about a possible compromise.

"I'm an advocate for the comunity of Ketchikan, for the jobs and families of Ketchikan, and I want to see a positive result," he said last week when he announced he was postponing an Asia trade mission to attend the Washington meeting, which he organized.

Louisiana-Pacific says that unless it gets a 15-year extension of its controversial contract for timber from the Tongass National Forest, and unless there is a repeal of several environmental reforms passed by Congress in the sweeping 1990 Tongass Timber Reform Act, it will close its Ketchikan mill.

Louisiana-Pacific chairman Mark Suwyn said the company needs an extension of the 50-year contract, now due to run out in 2004, and a rollback of environmental regulations, by this month to avert a shutdown.

Louisiana-Pacific has lost money in recent years on its entire pulp division, but mostly on the Ketchikan Pulp facility, which is more than 40 years old, needs at least $180 million in upgrades to meet regulations and the terms of a criminal settlement on pollution charges.

Ketchikan Pulp spokesman Troy Reinhart said the mill anticipates an annual loss of at least $40 million this year. He blamed that record on environmental restrictions wrought by the Tongass Timber Reform Act.
"If it wasn't for the Forest Service's illegal, unilateral contract modification that Congress directed it to do, we would be profitable. We would not be a drag on the company," Reinhart said.

Critics regard the Ketchikan Pulp contract as an anachronistic subsidy that harms the environment of the Tongass, the largest U.S. national forest, is costly to taxpayers and stifles market competition.
A contract-extending bill authored by Frank Murkowski, the Alaska Republican who chairs the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee, has encountered opposition from both political parties.
Knowles, a Democrat, said the state can do little more to ease Ketchikan Pulp's woes, pointing out that eight years remain on the current contract.
Ketchikan Pulp's fate is ultimately a business decision for Louisiana-Pacific, he said.

"I have no control over the world price of pulp or what their strategy is with their company in terms of what role pulp plays in Louisiana-Pacific's business strategy. You'll have to ask them," he said in a news conference.
Knowles has been under fire from Alaska Republicans who say he has done too little to protect Ketchikan Pulp from environmental policies of the Democratic Clinton administration.

In a campaign coordinated by a founder of the pro-development "Wise Use" movement, mill supporters have distributed bumper stickers and buttons that query: "Where's Tony?" -- accusing the governor of being a no-show in the Ketchikan Pulp battle.
Last week, before Knowles postponed his Asia trip, Suwyn joined the criticism of the governor.

"If it were my state, and my constituents were about to have the whole southeastern part of my state to be obliterated economically, i guess I would be extraordinarily involved," Suwyn told reporters last week in Washington.
